Name: Existentialist novel
Description: Fictional works exploring themes of existential philosophy, often focusing on individual freedom, choice, and the meaning of existence.

Name: Autobiography
Description: Personal narratives written by the subject, detailing their own life experiences and reflections.

Name: Fiction
Description: Imaginative storytelling that may or may not be based on real events or characters.

Name: Epic Poetry
Description: Long narrative poems often celebrating heroic deeds, legendary figures, or mythological tales.

Name: Classic Literature
Description: Timeless literary works that have enduring significance and are widely regarded as exemplary or noteworthy.

Name: Romantic Novel
Description: Fictional narratives emphasizing emotional and romantic themes, often centered around love stories.

Name: Children's literature
Description: Literature specifically created for and aimed at children, typically featuring age-appropriate themes, language, and illustrations.

Name: Adventure Fiction
Description: Narrative works characterized by exciting and daring exploits, often involving travel, exploration, or risk-taking.

Name: Literature
Description: Written works, including novels, poetry, plays, and essays, valued for their artistic merit, intellectual depth, and cultural significance.

Name: Memoir
Description: Personal accounts or recollections of one's own experiences, often focusing on specific periods, events, or themes in the author's life.

Name: Philosophical novel
Description: Fictional narratives that explore philosophical concepts, debates, or questions, often through character development and plot.

Name: Epic poetry
Description: Long narrative poems often celebrating heroic deeds, legendary figures, or mythological tales.

Name: Post-apocalyptic Fiction
Description: Fiction set in a world or society following a catastrophic event, exploring themes of survival, adaptation, and rebuilding.

Name: Philosophical literature
Description: Written works that delve into philosophical ideas, theories, or inquiries, often presented in literary form.

Name: Political Satire
Description: Literary works that use humor, irony, or sarcasm to critique or ridicule political figures, institutions, or ideologies.

Name: Novella
Description: Narrative works shorter than a novel but longer than a short story, offering a focused exploration of character, theme, or plot.

Name: Realism
Description: Literary movement or style characterized by the depiction of ordinary life, often focusing on everyday experiences and social realities.

Name: Semi-autobiographical novel
Description: Fictional works that draw heavily from the author's own life experiences, blurring the lines between autobiography and fiction.

Name: Epic Fantasy
Description: Narrative works set in fantastical worlds featuring epic quests, magical elements, and grand conflicts between forces of good and evil.

Name: Psychology
Description: Literature that explores psychological concepts, theories, or phenomena, offering insights into human behavior, cognition, and emotion.

Name: Fantasy
Description: Fictional narratives set in imaginary worlds or featuring fantastical elements such as magic, mythical creatures, or supernatural powers.

Name: Modernist novel
Description: Literary works produced during the modernist literary movement, characterized by experimental forms, stream-of-consciousness narration, and fragmented structures.

Name: Science
Description: Written works that explore scientific principles, theories, discoveries, or advancements, aimed at both general and specialized audiences.

Name: Mystery
Description: Narrative works centered around the investigation and resolution of a puzzling or enigmatic event, often involving crime, detection, and suspense.

Name: Horror
Description: Literary genre focused on eliciting fear, terror, or dread in the reader, often through supernatural, grotesque, or macabre elements.

Name: Quest Fiction
Description: Narrative works in which characters embark on a journey or mission, often facing challenges, obstacles, and personal growth along the way.

Name: Philosophical fiction
Description: Fictional narratives that use storytelling as a means to explore philosophical themes, ideas, or questions.

Name: War novel
Description: Fictional works that depict war and its impact on individuals, societies, and cultures, often exploring themes of heroism, sacrifice, and trauma.

Name: Satirical novel
Description: Narrative works characterized by satire, employing humor, irony, or sarcasm to criticize or lampoon aspects of society, politics, or human behavior.

Name: Children's Literature
Description: Literary works specifically created for children, designed to entertain, educate, or inspire young readers.

Name: Magic Realism
Description: Narrative genre blending realistic settings with magical or fantastical elements, often exploring themes of identity, culture, and perception.

Name: Tragedy
Description: Dramatic works depicting the downfall or suffering of a protagonist, often due to a tragic flaw or external circumstances, eliciting feelings of pity or fear.

Name: Multicultural Fiction
Description: Literary works that explore themes of cultural diversity, identity, and cross-cultural experiences, often reflecting the perspectives of marginalized or underrepresented groups.

Name: Historical Novel
Description: Fictional narratives set in the past, often incorporating real historical events, figures, or settings, offering insights into different time periods and societies.

Name: Allegorical Novel
Description: Narrative works in which characters, events, or settings represent abstract ideas.

Name: Picaresque novel
Description: Narrative works featuring a roguish, often humorous protagonist who travels through various adventures and encounters.

Name: Young Adult Fiction
Description: Literature aimed at adolescent readers, typically featuring themes and characters relevant to the experiences and interests of young adults.

Name: Crime Fiction
Description: Narrative works focused on crime, investigation, and detection, often featuring detectives, criminals, and suspenseful plot twists.

Name: Historical Fiction
Description: Fictional narratives set in the past, drawing inspiration from historical events, figures, and settings, while often incorporating imaginative elements.

Name: Science Fiction
Description: Narrative works exploring speculative or futuristic concepts, often centered around science, technology, and their potential impact on society.

Name: Dystopian Fiction
Description: Literature set in a dystopian society or future, characterized by oppressive social control, dehumanization, and often a bleak outlook on humanity.

Name: Gothic Fiction
Description: Literary genre characterized by a dark, mysterious atmosphere, supernatural elements, and themes of horror, death, and decay.

Name: Romance
Description: Narrative works focused on romantic relationships, love, and emotional connections between characters.

Name: Self-help
Description: Literature aimed at personal development and improvement, offering advice, strategies, and insights for achieving success, happiness, or fulfillment.
